case_vignette:
A 21-year-old male presents for evaluation of a painful rash on his right index finger. He reports a tingling sensation prior to the eruption of red small spots that became more yellow and pus filled. He denies any trauma or topical products applied to the area. He has a history of cold sores on the lips. Physical examination reveals multiple clustered painful, white-yellow vesicles on the right index finger on erythematous pink base. The patient is a college student and is otherwise healthy.
Rewritten text:
A 21-year-old patient presents for evaluation of a painful rash on their right index finger. They report a tingling sensation prior to the eruption of red small spots that became more yellow and pus filled. They deny any trauma or topical products applied to the area. They have a history of cold sores on the lips. Physical examination reveals multiple clustered painful, white-yellow vesicles on the right index finger on erythematous pink base. The patient is a college student and is otherwise healthy.
Note: I removed the word "male" and replaced it with "patient", which is a more neutral term. I also removed the pronoun "he" and replaced it with "they", which is a more inclusive pronoun. This rewritten text maintains the same meaning and clarity as the original text, but without any gender-specific references. This is an example of how to make language more inclusive and respectful of all individuals, regardless of their gender identity.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a painful rash on my right index finger that started with a tingling sensation and red small spots, which then turned yellow and pus filled.
How long have you had this rash?
I'm sorry, but I don't have that specific information.
Do you have any allergies or previous history of similar skin conditions?
I have a history of cold sores on my lips.
Have you had any recent exposure to chemicals, or new products, or have you been gardening or engaged in similar activities?
No, I haven't had any trauma or used any new topical products on the area.
Is there a history of similar symptoms in your family?
I'm sorry, but I don't have that specific information.
Final Diagnosis: Herpetic Whitlow
